question_text: A 50-year-old man is evaluated for a slowly evolving lesion on the dorsal aspect of the left arm.Skin findings are shown.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: The most likely diagnosis is squamous cell carcinoma (Option D). As in this case, squamous cell carcinoma presents as a slowly evolving, isolated keratotic or eroded macule, papule, or nodule. It most commonly appears on sun-exposed skin, including the face, scalp, neck, pinna, lip, or extremities.In contrast, a basal cell carcinoma typically demonstrates a heaped-up waxy or pearly border, whereas a keratoacanthoma usually presents as a rapidly growing nodule with a central area of keratinized material.
